title: Jose Mourinho says he felt "safe and comfortable" in Russia amid hooliganism concerns ahead of World Cup
text:

Jose Mourinho addressed safety concerns in Russia following his side's 2-1 aggregate win over FC Rostov in the Europa League last-16 on Thursday. 
The Manchester United boss was asked whether he and his players felt threatened in the country amid the fear of hooliganism ahead of the 2018 World Cup. 
England fans were targeted by Russian mobs during Euro 2016 in France, and subsequent threats of violence towards supporters have since been made. 
A recent BBC Two documentary entitled This World: Russia's Hooligan Army followed the Orel Butchers and brought further attention to the problem. Jose Mourinho discussed safety concerns in Russia following Man United's tie with FC Rostov (Photo: Danny Lawson/PA Wire) 
The programme focused on one gang who claim to be preparing attacks on England supporters in Moscow next year. 
Ahead of the first-leg of the Red Devils' last-16 game, Man United's travelling fans were advised not to wear club colours and to stay in groups while in Russia. 
Speaking after the Europa League tie, Mourinho discussed safety in the country based on his own experience from his side's February game. The Orel Butchers featured in the This World: Russia's Hooligan Army documentary (Photo: BBC) 
He told reporters: "My view was that everything went wonderfully well in Russia, apart from the pitch. 
"But the club was so nice to us, the people around the hotel and airport were so nice. Mourinho said he felt "safe" in Russia when his side faced FC Rostov in the first leg (Photo: REUTERS) 
"I think the same with our supporters in the stadium, I never felt anything but safe and super comfortable. 
"I couldn't smell any kind of problem." Juan Mata scored the only goal of Man United's 1-0 win over FC Rostov at Old Trafford (Photo: Getty Images) 
Man United drew 1-1 with FC Rostov at the Olimp-2, with Henrikh Mkhitaryan grabbing a crucial away goal on a difficult playing surface.
